title: Phrack Pro-Phile XXIII: The Mentor
historical_context: This article provides insight into the life and contributions of Loyd, known as The Mentor, a significant figure in the hacking and phreaking community during the late 1980s.
target_audience: Hackers, phreakers, security professionals, and those interested in hacker culture history.
short_summary: This article profiles Loyd, a prominent hacker known as The Mentor, detailing his early experiences with computers, his involvement in the hacking community, and his contributions to various hacking publications.
summary:
In this engaging profile, Taran King introduces readers to Loyd, a notable figure in the hacking and phreaking scene of the late 1980s. Loyd's journey began at the age of 13 when he gained access to university mainframes, sparking a lifelong passion for hacking. His early experiences included creating trojan horses and fake front ends to gain unauthorized access to systems, showcasing the resourcefulness and ingenuity that characterized many hackers of the time. Loyd's involvement in various bulletin board systems (BBS) and his connections with other influential hackers highlight the collaborative nature of the hacking community during this era.

The article also touches on Loyd's academic background in computer science and his work as a graphics programmer, illustrating how his professional skills complemented his hacking activities. Notably, he was an active member of the Legion of Doom, a well-known hacking group, and contributed to several hacking publications, including Phrack. Loyd's experiences, memorable encounters, and insights into the hacker lifestyle provide a fascinating glimpse into the culture and mindset of hackers during a pivotal time in the evolution of computer security and hacking practices.
